I don't wanna make my own thread just for this but does anyone have any suggestions on shorts for me? I don't want super short shorts (just above the knee). I'm having trouble looking on Amazon. I have 32" inseam and 30" waist. Sizing guides all say I should have a small but I'm afraid that the shorts would run too high.
I don't want pockets but I want something to keep my junk from going everywhere
Same here. I don't drink coffee but 90% of my runs are fasted. Sometimes I'll wake up, go to a two hour class, and then run. Breakfast is always amazing, even if it's a burnt piece of toast.

You need to ease into minimalist shoes. You don't have the muscles to support that kind of running if you were using conventional shoes. I had all sorts of issues with cushioned and dropped shoes. Transitioning into minimalist shoes has running much more pleasurable for me.

Yeah it snows in the desert. I live in the San Juans, the mountain range not too far west of there (relatively). We got a nice little storm role through during spring break. It dumped 2' in the valley and 4' up high. My roommate went to the Grand Canyon because, why not? He's from the Basque Country and its spring break. They get close to 5' and spent the weekend in a hotel. Spring Break woo!
But yeah, it snows a decent amount around there. It's kinda high. I'm guessing around 5,000'

One time I was forced to lead. It was on a bike but it is the same situation.
I'm biking up one of my favorite climbs. I've done it countless times. I was planning on averaging 13 mph. My pr is 14.5, I'm sore, yesterday was a big day of climbing.So, I'm gonna take it easy.
At the bottom of this climb I see this guy. He's old. He's going at a snails pace. I sped up to 17 mph as I passed him and I held that for a hundred meters or so. I thought I got some distance on him but I notice something. There's this shadow that's following me. I turn around to see that this is Ned Overend. A mountain biking legend, who just so happens to live where I do.
I wanna drop him. He's not gonna pass me. He's just gonna sit on my wheel. I start with an attack but he held on. I picked up the pace and then attacked, he held on. This kept going on. At one point, we were going 17 mph up a 7% slope. I couldn't imagine doing that before but every time I looked back there was a 59 year old man looking fresher than a daisy.
The road flattened out before this one, very short, 10% wall. I dug deep and went into the red because that was the end. I drop Ned at the beginning of the climb but he catches me on a flat part of road and smokes me on the descent.
When he passed me he spoke for the first and last time. "This is where the fun part starts!"

I'm riding on a velobuild frame and it's great! I built it not too long ago. A thousand miles in and I have no complaints.

If that reporters investigation is grounds for the claim "everyone is microdosing", you are wrong. What he showed is it is POSSIBLE to beat the system. It is a modal claim, not a prescriptive one.
In a conditional it could be written as:
If everyone is microdosing, they will pass the biological pass port.
Or
M P If M Then P.
This argument form is just a modus ponens.
If you were to say:
M P
If P
Then M
You would be affirming the consequent, which is one of the two formal logical fallacies. That is what you said. Let's not affirm the consequent and talk about the mere possibly of microdosing in the pro peloton. We cannot say thay they are doping or that they or not
I guarantee you they drop the register before it ever hits $400

WRITING.TEXT: What do y'all think of Paul Galvin? I mentioned to an Irish fella in a bar that we are second cousins. I was the sole cause and end to the fight.
There have been recorded deaths. I think the lowest was either 12 mg or 20mg. If you are eating 100 ug hits, that would be 120 - 200 hits
You gotta watch out for the navy folks though. I also grew up near West Point and there was always a debate of Navy vs Army football
Chemo is not on par with migraine. I am not trying to say that. It is an argument from analogy
Read my comment below. I expanded upon what I intended to say. Hopefully it helps you understand where I am coming from.

That's quite the assumption. If I were some High Schooler, would that mean my comments have less strength because it comes from a high schooler?
Also FartToast, I used to get migraines a couple times a month. I have to call out of work, lay in a dark room and just lay there until its over. I'll faint if I stand up for more than a minute. I'll get sick until theres is nothing to come up and then its just dry heaving. Sometimes that lasts two days.
A simple tension headache is not something you can compare. I'll tell my boss that I'm having a migraine and I need to have someone cover. She'll just say, "whats wrong? I have a migraine and I'm working right now." I have to explain the difference and then she gets it.
Too many people equivocate the terms. A migraine is a very difficult experience that most people try to relate with when they really cannot. That is no different than going up to a chemo patient and saying "yeah I had the flu once, I know how you feel", when you really have no idea what its like.
They aren't comparable. Completely different pain
Don't say migraine if you just mean really bad headache. Migraines are crippling. It's discourteous to those who actually have migraines.
Maybe in the 60s but definitely not today.

It would be hard unless you have had a similar experience. Everything was extremely detailed and bright. I was mountain biking in the middle of the night up this gulgh and my light died. I discovered I didn't need a light because I could see everything. I would occasionally stop for what felt like hours but I when I would continue moving and check back into reality, the same song was playing. That happened a lot.
This mountain started spiriling into itself. It kind of looked that mountain from *The Grinch*. Rocks shine colors that I had never seen before but I some how am able to recall them now. It was very iridescent and strangely purple.
I felt like I had an unlimited source of energy. I just kept going and going. I went for a 15 mile ride and followed it with a ten mile walk. I went to work later that day still beaming with energy
Holy shit I had an "accent trip" once. Everyone at this festival had an Australian accent. I kept asking everyone I met where they were from. It was usually LA or San Francisco.
This. I took eight 250ug hits of fluff one night. That's closer to 20 *regular* hits. I've never had an experience that was that difficult to describe before

CEFHCL understood that concern. His comment directly addressed it. Now this is getting circular. Also, we are discussing two different forms of ethics (or grounds for deciding what makes an action good or bad).
The UCI puts rules in place to prevent poor consequences. The idea of allowing the act because it is based in a good maxim is deontological. So the debate really boils down into the consequentialist/deontology debate.
This sub generally has some good debates but this is an ethical debate. You bet we need to have a good debate and not hold any view so dear that we wouldn't be able to abandon it if it were clearly the weaker view.
It's a shame that Richie was docked two minutes. Clarke's sentiment will undoubtedly be acknowledged in cycling history
Oh grow up because we are all getting older

I was at the bar and needed to break the seal. Zip, ssssss, and bling! What's that? I look up and there is a game that measures the velocity at which I was peeing. I peed as hard as I could (do your kegals everyone!) and got first place on the leaderboards. The idea of a touchscreen above a urinal is a little strange but that was the biggest accomplishment of my entire trip, peeing really fast in a bar.

I did my first 2,000 miles or three months in gym shorts, including an imperial century with 10k of climbing. I didn't have any issues. I kept my phone and snacks in my pocket and often rode shirtless in the summer.

I think I found my mom's reddit account.

The town I grew up in was beautiful in the fall when the leaves changed. It was a small town, just a couple thousand people. It sat on the Hudson River and was easily accessed from New York City by a 50 minute train ride. At 10:15 AM on the Saturday of "peak color week" as declared by the New York, there is a line of Asians flooding up Main Street to this one tree. At least a couple hundred Asians congested the one stop light where the tree sat adjacent to.
It was a beautiful tree on the lawn of a 400 year old church but goddamn did the Asian tourists love it. They always asked for directions to this one particular pizza place. Being the asshole of a teenager that we were, we sent them to random buildings in town and had them knocking on the doors
I dated a black girl. We hit up the hot springs one day. There were 20 something small, hot tub esque, pools and one large pool that was seven feet deep. We never went into that pool.

My Dad doesn't have a lot of certifications but he has a lifetime of experience. He got out of the Marine Corps and started working on Wall Street, making six figures in the late 80s.
Now he is a freelancer, driving around the state and making what he needs to support his hiking and hangliding habits

I got hit by a car when I was biking. Driver was negligent. The cop heard his side of the story. Walked up to me, gave me his card with the case number and drove away.
I was at fault. Driver got a new door because "I dented it". I hit the hood of the car. He got a new door two weeks later. I fought his insurance company for five months before they sent a $17,000 check for $24,000 worth of hospital bills (not to mention a $3,000 bike). The fucker got a new door before my skull fracture healed

He probably meant to say it tastes like shit in the states. Guiness in the isles isn't pasteurized (or something like that). You can totally tell the difference between draft Guiness from a pub in Ireland and Guiness of any form in the states. The prior tastes like a milk shake
It has the same geometry and a BBright shell (like those found in Cervelos). The carbon layup is different but the bike is intended to replicate an R5
I was being cautious as to how much I torqued those bolts. In guessing too cautious because they went from vertical to that in just 15 miles. I fixed it and put it at 5nm (what 3t recommends).

You can probably figure it out from my comment history, Durango Colorado. Just up 25th street... which is just the junction creek forrest service road. It's just up the road from the Colorado trail's trailhead. This is 10 miles up that road, or just past the animas overlook. It's a great climb if you don't mind the dirt!

I've never ridden an R5 so I couldn't compare but I have ridden a SuperSixEvo Hi Mod for comparison. It's a really stiff frame and smooth too. I doubt most consumers would be able to tell the difference between a high end Chinese carbon frame and a high end Cervelo frame.
I would totally recommend this frame in particular. The cable routing was pretty easy, it looks nice, and has ridden well thus far. I've only ridden it 40 miles so I couldn't say much.

Six months ago I got hit and this is the settlement money for the property damages. This is my first time building a bike so I went with velobuild. It was experiment but I like how it turned out!
Frame: UD finish on VB-R-055 (it's basically a Cervelo R5)
Wheels: VB-R-38-23 38mm
Grouppo: Ultegra 11sp
Crank: Mid-compact
Cassette: 11-28 (all I really do is climb so...)
Stem: 110mm 3T ARX Pro
Handlebars: Zipp Service Course 70 Ergo 40cm Drop Bar
Saddle: Fizik Arione TT Wingflex
Tires: Continental Grand Prix 25mm

Sweet thanks for the help! I found a new BB for $35 online so I went with that. Should I go to the shops around town and see if they have the right size drift and pay them a couple bucks to do it real quick?

Also, none of the shops in town carry Cervelo (BBright is Cervelo proprietary). There are a good number of former pros or olympic mechanics wrenching around that will probably know what parts I need but I'm afraid they are going try to order parts online and sell me something more expensive than I need (that has happened in the past).
It's easy to find a $10,000 road bike.

I got a kitten for my Christmas when I was younger. I named him Dash. I moved across the country for College and I told my Mom that I would bring Dash with me when I got a house.
I really liked Dash, we were homies. My Mom moved and apparently her new neighbors like Dash too. They named him **Sox**. They fed him whatever he asked for. He kept getting food poisoning. His liver failed. He was only three years old. I was two months away from getting him.
Please tell me you didn't kill Sox
Job security

Climbing is a fun challenge. Flat roads are boring. Pushing hard up a climb is fun. You might not look so pretty but the pain feels good. Bonus, you get to go really fast to make up for how slow you went up the climb.
Your flair says your from Colorado. I'm guessing you live in the front range where you have the option to ride flat stuff. There are five ways out of my town and all but one involve a couple thousand feet of climbing.
Interesting. I'll probe around for more opinions. Thanks!
I like the responses in favor of Your Flesh. Anyone wanna play devils advocate? Because I'm probably going to go back there.

WRITING.TITLE: Who is your favorite tattoo artist in town?
WRITING.TEXT:
Because I'm getting a tattoo sometime soon, I am asking people for their opinions and experiences with artists in town. My experiences thus far have been mixed. I got a simple tattoo at your flesh but the experience was great. Skin inc is on my no fly list and blue dragon is on my no tattoo list.
I want to get an oak tree on my calf/foot, possibly integrating a wren into it. I have some ideas about what I want it too look like but I want an artist to bounce ideas off of.
Who would you recommend for not only the tattooing but designing a tattoo? Who's creative, good at listening, and skilled? or should I just go to a reputable shop in a big city?
The monument isn't even at four corners. It's a Navajo tourist trap. The frybread is aight

Were you in decent cardiovascular shape before hand? I moved from sea level to 7,500. Day one I was running at about the same pace as before. If you have already have a high red blood cell count (read: endurance athlete) then elevation won't kill you.

The CT (Colorado Trail) starts a block from my house. There are hundreds of miles of world class mountain biking (think downhill and cross country world tour stops) trails whose trail heads start no more than three blocks away. Best part of it all, the trails are always empty. Denver is cool but the other side of the Rockies are where it's at.
If you ever say "I'm bored" you deserve to get slapped back to California

I wouldn't imagine this subreddit is generally open to acid but I think its an amazing combination. Anyone who says it's dangerous has either neither taken acid or learned how to be in control of themselves on acid. I can bike for hours and not feel fatigued (but you still gotta eat).
